title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act is titled the "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006" and includes the establishment of the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established in the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, covering approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a final map and boundary description to Congress, with the map available for public inspection. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia covers 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide a map and boundary description for public inspection. Management includes protecting scenic quality, water resources, wildlife habitat, and natural characteristics. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia covers 13,382 acres and management includes protecting scenic quality, water resources, wildlife habitat, and natural characteristics. The management plan for the area must provide wildlife and fish habitat, develop old-growth forests, and offer various recreation opportunities. In case of conflicts, the management purposes specified in the plan take precedence over general laws and regulations applicable to the National Forest System. The Secretary must develop a management plan for the scenic area within three years of the Act's enactment, conforming to the specified requirements. After the enactment of the Act, no new roads can be built in the Chattahoochee National Forest scenic area, except for access to private lands. Timber harvesting is prohibited, except for fire control, insect/disease management, public safety, and trail access. The Secretary may conduct vegetation manipulation for wildlife maintenance. The Secretary may engage in vegetation manipulation for wildlife maintenance and authorize motorized travel within the scenic area for administrative use. Wildfires shall be suppressed in a manner consistent with management purposes, and insect/disease outbreaks may be addressed. The scenic area may be managed to control insect and disease outbreaks, maintain water quality, and withdraw federally owned lands from mining activities. Designation of additional national forest system land as wilderness in Georgia. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres of land in Georgia as wilderness, adding to existing wilderness areas in Chattahoochee National Forest. Includes additions to Southern Nantahala, Blood Mountain, and Brasstown Wilderness areas. The curr_chunk describes the addition of various parcels of land to existing wilderness areas in Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. These additions include Duck Branch, Wilson Cove, Ellicott Rock Addition, Foster Branch, Ken Mountain, Helton Creek, and Tripp Branch, totaling 8,448 acres. The Secretary is required to submit final maps and boundary descriptions to Congress. The Secretary must submit final maps and boundary descriptions of the designated wilderness lands to Congress. The maps will be available for public inspection, and the lands will be administered in accordance with the Wilderness Act. The designated wilderness lands are withdrawn from all forms of entry, appropriation, or disposal under the public. This section does not affect the jurisdiction or responsibilities of the State of Georgia with respect to fish and wildlife in the Chattahoochee National Forest. The designated wilderness lands are withdrawn from entry, appropriation, or disposal under public land laws, mining laws, and laws pertaining to mineral and geothermal leasing or mineral materials.
